Gordon - 

A personal dilemma. Last March I've purchased a beautiful mumei katana with fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae which had damage. I've had the sword put into shirazaya and a tsunagi made for the koshirae with repairs, on-going. Because the tsuka wrapping was literally falling apart, the fuchi/kashira and menuki were removed and therefore, able to be examined in-hand. The menuki are solid gold "dragons" which are super! The fuchi/kashira (mumei) are even more fine and really do cry for shinsa with an eye toward Goto. The kozuka/kogai looked "mainline Goto" but drew (reportedly) a generic "Goto den" call from the NBTHK. 

My dilemma, should these wonderful fitting be placed back on the sword or be kept seperately and "boxed" for individual preservation and appreciation. I say "dilemma" but in all honesty my choice has been made; they will be boxed for individual in-hand appreciation. So, should I feel bad to have in a sense "destroyed" a koshirae or should I feel good to have discovered these wonderful kodogu. Granted, the koshirae was not truly a (and I hate this expression) "matching" koshirae and was really "put together" by it pre-war owner. Yes, I'll keep the saya and (unmounted) tsuka together with a tsunagi but it seems such a waste to put these beautiful fitting back on it where they can be damaged (f/k, kozuka/kogai) or hidden under ito (menuki). 

After saying all this I'm not too sure where I'm going with it, but my point might be that there is a time to "preserve" a koshirae" and a time to not worry about it. 

Ron

  I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
  They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
  off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
  keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is not
  touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure this
  is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
  you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
  mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
  be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
  maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for antique
  firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
  value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.



  Jim, care to comment?



  Gordon
